Poor implementation of an otherwise good product.

The JetBrains plugin for GitHub Copilot is far behind what is provided for VS Code and other platforms.

  1. Chat UI is broken, with messages being duplicated.
  2. A ton of features are missing (things like @workspace and @terminal don't even exist, attach doesn't exist)
  3. The "agent progress" UI is buggy.
  4. Tab completion seems worse than what's present in VS Code. In fact, Jetbrains' built in heuristic based code complete works much better than copilot in many contexts.

If your primary IDE is an intellij based one, GitHub Copilot is definitely not worth the asking price. These IDEs will always remain a third-class citizen in the ecosystem since it looks like most of the development bandwidth is dedicated to VS code and the Visual Studio ecosystem.

Maybe Copilot is coding itself, and I’m just talking to a bot on the support line. That would actually explain a lot.

It’s completely broken. It used to work perfectly fine, but then, out of nowhere, it just stopped working on my MacOS. Windows seems to be okay, but I can’t speak for everyone else. It's like they flipped a switch and decided, “No more functionality for you.”

I submitted a complaint to GitHub support, and the response has been laughable. Every 3-4 days, I get some generic reply asking for logs—logs that I already sent in my very first message. They seem more interested in playing email ping-pong than actually solving the problem. They’re dragging this out as if that’s somehow going to fix the issue. Spoiler: It’s not.

Oh, and let’s not forget who owns GitHub now—Microsoft. It’s hard to shake the feeling that this is just some underhanded way to nudge us towards their clunky VS version. Honestly, if that’s the plan, it’s not working; it’s only making me hate them more.
The authorization flow is broken; I cannot log in or use it.

Copilot Chat feature totally broken. Nags me about requiring additional authorization, then when I try to proceed, it logs me out. It worked so far, and wrecked by a recent update. How could such a blatant bug pass the beta release?
Latest update completely breaks Copilot Chat (completions still work), it claims that it needs "Additional Authorization" and then spins endlessly in "Checking Copilot Chat prerequisites".

This is the single most frustrating piece of software I ever got to use.

It's wonderful when it works, but boy is it NOT often. There's ALWAYS some kind of bug that prevent me from using it and driving me nuts, and it's been like that for months.

I can't wrap my head around how there are so much bugs and it's working fine like 20% of the time. New bug right now: stuck on "Checking Copilot Chat prerequisites".

Worst of it is I paid a full year of this. The sooner it ends, the sooner I get a proper stuff like SuperMaven.

The auto-completion is annoyingly stupid, produces either blatantly copy-pasted code that is not right in the given context or produces code that doesn't even compile.

The context is limited to the opened tabs, which forces me to open more tabs than I want... also annoying...

IntelliJ's single line code completion is better than this...

When it works, it slows things down to a crawl. You never know if it's going to suggest something or just crap out. Then when it does suggest something, it's often garbage code. GitHub, maybe you should stick to hosting code and leave AI to the pros like OpenAI and the many others.

Well, this is not a review. Yet, it might be somehow useful to the community. As a user of both JetBrains PyCharm EAPs and GitHub Copilot, I am somehow disappointed by the (lack of) support from GitHub of recent EAP builds (for no clear reason). After some unsuccessful interaction with GitHub support (understandable from a corporate standpoint; much less so from a customer satisfaction one!) I decided to roll my own (very trivial) solution: to forcefully remove version upper bounds from the plugin. Of course, it requires manual plugin download (as a zipfile) and some further .jar unzipping interleaved with a sed substitution. But here it is a script to do that automagically: https://gist.github.com/emaballarin/18852984fe087e869262295e6218e7d3

In the case of the Copilot plugin, the invocation line should look something like: jbppatch "github-copilot-intellij" "1.5.25.28-nightly" with the plugin downloaded in the invocation directory and eventually the numbers adapted to filename.

Enjoy!

I gotta be honest. I feel like this Copilot for IntelliJ is actually getting worse.

  • It will repeatedly give suggestions that have already been identified as wrong, for example.
  • The suggestions that it makes hardly ever work.
  • If you include any form of personal frustration, trying to interact with this Copilot in a human way, it will often reject your request and refuse to interact with you for trying to interact with it in such a human way.
  • The Copilot for VS Code seems to be leaving this IntelliJ Copilot in the dust. On VS Code Copilot, you can tell it to take the entire project into context, or you can easily reference individual files. Additionally, it just seems to give better suggestions.

I am using GitHub Copilot Enterprise; it's getting worse every day! The performance and quality of suggestions or bug fixes were really good a few months back, but now they are just mediocre and weak.

Copilot did not keep up with UX compared to other providers, which is saddening. I don't mind paying more if it works well and saves me time, but there is no higher plan to buy...

The interface for fixing the code is highly outdated and has not kept pace with industry developments. It was considered revolutionary three years ago, but now it seems strange and underdeveloped. Surprisingly, despite receiving significant funding, the plugin has not been improved to meet modern standards.

Excellent tool when you know its limitations.

It's obvious it won't write the code for me, but it's priceless when generating tests or documentation for the existing code.

It works quite well when talking about optimizing the current code plus when there is a need to explain the existing code.

It produces code that is incorrect much of the time. This would be less of a issue if the answers didn't look right. Problem is, most of the suggestions require detailed examination in order to discover that they are in fact useless.

By the time you've figured that out you could have found a working solution, had a cup of coffee, a natter with your workmates, and an argument about cats on social media !

Version: 1.5.23.6819 Ide: Build #IU-242.22855.74

In general it works well, but there are many nuances to work on:

  • It needs faster problem-solving updates.
  • Keeping up with its VSCode counterpart in terms of functionality.
  • Updating basic features that have been waiting for months, such as not breaking the autocomplete of all plugins for one that "works", but in exchange for disabling others that complement it.
  • Activating the AI's memory, it doesn't make sense to have to repeat the same phrase every day like "I want you to answer me in X language ALWAYS". Although it is not vital, it is inconsistent that it loses some basic context information.
  • Allowing integration with databases, and thus mitigating hallucinations with the fields that the tables have.
  • Mitigating its hallucinations. If you ask for example "sort the content of a file alphabetically and nothing else", forget its pro-activity and invent keys that do not exist. Many times it doesn't matter how precise you are with your instructions, they literally do what they want.
Please support version 2024.3 EAP

Copilot’s core functionality is great and really boosts productivity. I love how it integrates smoothly with the IDE. However, the UI could use more customization options. Also, the localization needs work. It would be awesome if Copilot could match the IDE's language settings, like Chinese, to make the suggestions and UI more relevant for non-English users.

Looking forward to improvements!

The plugin itself works fine most of the time (at least for me).

However, since it's a paid plugin, if you are considering subscribing to GitHub Copilot, please beware of the following:

  • The plugin lacks significantly comparing to VsCode one. The Roadmap or at least some ETA for key features like agents are nowhere to be found. And new features are added (if at all) months after getting introduced (and advertised) in VsCode.
  • Installing this plugin automatically disables the built-in full line completion and likely many other similar plugins, because the plugin uses a deprecated API for inline suggestions. The request to migrate to a proper API is now almost half a year old (https://github.com/orgs/community/discussions/116679), and no one from GitHub even responded.
  • Copilot pricing/features pages list things that are not actually available in Jetbrains plugin without explicitly mentioning that (e.g. commit messages, agents, etc)
  • Support is nearly non-existent. Most of the docs/pages direct you to their community page (https://github.com/community/community/discussions/categories/copilot) with a list of issues, but almost no one from GitHub actually bothers answering questions there - try to filter issues by Copilot and Jetbrains labels and see how many of those got answered (40% at best), and how many of those answered were actually answered by someone from GitHub (probably 10%).

Overall, it really feels like the plugin is developed by an understaffed team and is a low priority for the company. And it's such a shame, because it's a good plugin, but it could have been a great one.

Suggestion: For writing comments change the color of suggestions to be different from comments. In the popular Dark/Darcula Appearance setting, the color of suggestions is the same as the color of comments. Therefore, when you're writing comments it is very distracting, because your attention will move from your thoughts to the suggestions - to check if they are okay or not.

Currently 1 star because it sends IDEA in a freeze loop which I can only break by starting IDEA without projects from the CLI (dontReopenProjects) and then disabling the plugin. This is unacceptable.

Otherwise, I became quite used to the chat. I consider it a search engine with less typing and clicking, but no more. Results vary. If a web search would produce thousands of hits for a query then the copilot will usually summarize and adapt them to the local context quite well. Hard-to-google problems result in convoluted bla-bla or downright fantasy.
